author: chucklu
body:
there's an opt-in File Explorer context-menu integration in the installer (wizard) GUI.
I have ticked this option.
 
The problem is when I try to pop up the powershell in empty space of a folder, you provide submenus.
![default](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3004057/38474725-bbb3fe88-3bd4-11e8-8376-ef266259190a.png)
It's boring for me to choose open here and open as Administrator.
I already set it open as Administrator by default, so I hope you can make it as "git bash here" directly without submenus.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: It come from that we want have some versions installed side-by-side.

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body:
When I did the PR #5774 for this feature of the referenced issue #5012 , this got already discussed, see those 2 items for details.
The main reason for having the submenu is the  limitation of Windows registry options for context menus: they only allow direct elevation of the process using sub menus.
Apart from that the entry name would also become very long since it also needs to include version and bitness due to side-by-side installations to disambiguate.
The installer option is only setting some registry keys. If you do not like it, you can set your own registry keys for your preferred context menu, there are plenty of blogs on the Internet how to do that.
Therefore I would rather close this issue since there isn't really a viable alternative that a substantial amount of users would find useful. Sure, you could add another checkbox to the installer that only gives you one menu entry without a submenu but then the installer UI gets more complex (often leading to most users being overloaded by too much choice). What are your thoughts @SteveL-MSFT on whether we should provide more customisation?

comments.author: chucklu
comments.body:
@bergmeister  not sure, you can see "git bash here" in my screenshot(it did not contains version number).
The version should not show in context menu, we can check the  version by cmd.

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body:
@chucklu In contrast to git or git bash, multiple versions of PowerShell Core can be installed and the majority of users need to know that. As per my previous answer the main point of using submenus is due to the technical limitation of not being able to offer an elevated option in the main menu, hence why the menu options cannot be flat.
Also please consider that this feature should be a best fit for the majority of users and not just your case, you only describe a very minor inconvenience in your special case.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
I agree with @bergmeister that the issue of having a submenu was discussed in the links he provided and we ended up with the current design due to limitations of WIndows registry settings that enable this as well as supporting side-by-side installs of PSCore6

cc @joeyaiello

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body: @iSazonov I think this is an issue that can be closed as 'by design' since we have reasoned the technical design decision behind the need for the submenu and therefore it's a 'won't fix' item

title: Do not provide two submenus in file explorer integration
